newsitem.title: UK: Treasuries lose nerve in London ahead of Humphrey.
newsitem.headline: Treasuries lose nerve in London ahead of Humphrey.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries held Tokyo's lower levels in London on Friday, with the market starting to show its nerves ahead of Congressional testimony from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan next week.

"We've actually seen some buying in the 10-year note but we got hit on some bonds earlier in the session from a Japanese seller," said a trader at a U.S. bank in London. "But we haven't seen the trade substantiated."
The trader said the cash market may be taking its cue from the futures market, which slid through initial support in automated trade.
The benchmark long bond was quoted at 101-15, sitting on the key 6.5 percent yield at 0955 GMT, compared with 101-17 in Tokyo and 101-24 at New York's close.
According to GovPX, volume was roughly $3.48 billion.
September T-bond futures were quoted at 114-10, down 11/32 and below support at Thursday's CBOT pit settlement of 114-17.

Data out this session include May international trade, which was expected to show a widening of the trade gap to $9.18 billion from $8.36 billion in April and the preliminary survey from the University of Michigan for July, seen largely steady on June's 104.5 reading.
But analysts said the data would likely be overshadowed by Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on monetary policy and economic conditions before a House Banking subcommittee on Tuesday.
"The market has had a good run...but it still has a positive tone to it," said Dick Howard, senior economist at Bank Julius Baer in London. "It's now going to worry about Greenspan."
He said the market would be keen to see whether Greenspan would say anthing about whether productivity growth can continue to curb inflation as the U.S. economy continues to chug along.
Antennae would also be tuned to anything he says about equity prices after the Dow Jones Industrial Average streaked past the 8,000 barrier on Wednesday.
